question.title: most efficient way to add "host" with current hostname of an instance, in clusterred environment
question.body:
I'm trying to add a Global Variable named host that dynamically reflects the current instance where the application is running.

I'm working with TIBCO BW 5 applications, which are configured via .xml files on the front end, and run as pure Java code on the backend.

What I've tried so far:

  • Manual injection into Application.xml: This works, but only when I manually set the value per instance. Without a proper script to inject the correct value on Instance A and another for Instance B, deployment in a clustered environment doesn't behave as expectedâ€”it ends up using the hardcoded value.
  • Modifying bwengine.tra and designer.tra: I attempted this based on suggestions from various LLMs, but unfortunately, it had no effect.
  • Using a shared .projlib or manipulating the .jar: I explored both options, but neither yielded a successful outcome.

Note: I'm specifically looking for a solution that does not involve using the Administrator GUI.

Has anyone encountered this issue before or found a reliable workaround?

answers.body:
It depends from what you are trying to acheive.

If the goal is just to expose BusinessWorks HTTP endpoints to a load balancer you can do the following:

. Configure the HTTP connection resource with hostname set to localhost
. Use the bw.plugin.http.server.defaultHost property and set it also to localhost

The mentioned property can be set once for all by adding the following line in the bwengine.tra file:
java.property.bw.plugin.http.server.defaultHost=localhost

You can also set it at deployment time by following the explanations available in the 'Setting Custom Engine Properties in Deployed Projects' section of the BusinessWorks Administrator guide.

If the goal is to set a given hostname for each BusinessWorks engine in the runtime environment you can do the following:

. Create a Global Variable and configure it with the Service option
. Use this Global Variable to set the hostname of your HTTP connection resource
. Then at Deployment time in the Advanced tab available at the Service instance level set the Global Variable value to the desired value for each Service instance

There is no way to set the hostname dynamically and this won't really make sence because a machine can have multiple hostnames.

Regards

Emmanuel
